monogr.title: Eastern Christians’ Engagement with Islam and the Qurʾān: Texts, Contexts and Knowledge Regimes

biblStruct.note: This chapter examines three Christian Arabic apologetic texts from the period 1000-1350 (by Eliyā of Nisibis, by Paul of Antioch, and the anonymous Letter from the People of Cyprus), to ask how their qualified affirmation of Islam (and, in the latter two texts, of the Qur’ān and Muḥammad’s prophethood) affected their presentation of Christianity itself.
